This is useful but looks really complicated. maybe add some examples in the doc?

@winstywang @gengyifeng @tornadomeet @sxjscience please have a look and evaluate if this is easy enough to understand

the node id is mainly for the correct ordering, because we indeed relies on the node_id ordering for the summation( the first assignment need to come first). Due to the topo sort nature of and reverse topo traversal, this condition could be in general satisfied, but maybe I am missing somehting here

@piiwrong I can definitely do that. Where should the examples go? In the description field of the 'shape' param of Reshape? Or elsewhere?

Edit: Should I add a ReshapeDoc to https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/symbol_doc.py ?

BTW, the right way to think about this thing is as a little automata or machine that walks the input dimensions and the target shape simultaneously and produces the output dimensions. Which is already how it worked before -- that's what `0` did, for example -- it copied the corresponding dim from the input dims to the output dims.

Now it gets some more operations, like taking two input dims and only emitting one output dim, or taking one input dim and emitting two output dims. That way the rank of your output can be different from the rank of your input, but the way it chooses the dimensions is guaranteed to be valid as long as the rest of the spec is also valid.

So if you just imagine this little machine walking along the input dims and writing to the output dims it's quite easy to 'read' the instructions in your head. My existing addition to the description of 'shape' explains the math of this precisely, but a more intuitive explanation would also be useful.
I think examples should go reshape.cc in describe

@piiswrong Ok I added examples for each code. Let me know if you want me to reformat or tweak that description in any way. I could add a line of English for some of those examples if particular ones are unclear.

In the unmerging part, why do we need to use (-4, seqlen, -1, -2) instead of (-4, seqlen, -2)?
@piiswrong on master
output = [hidden \* 1] also works.

@sxjscience Your syntax `(-4, seqlen, -2)` would require a special case, the two 'arguments' to Split2 currently have to be ordinary positive integers (although ONE of them can be -1, to mean that it is equal to the original input length divided by the other integer). 

I can add that case for `-2`, but to me it only really makes sense in the second position to Split2, like what you wrote. The other way round, `(-4, -2, seqlen)`, would 'mix up' the higher dimensions in a weird non-local way. Do any of other codes make sense as arguments to Split2? Let's think. `0` would just copy the input dimension you're splitting, so the other dimension would be forced to be `1`. That's pretty useless. `-3` and `-4` seem pretty complicated to support and I'm trying to think what kind of interpretation these have. 

So maybe I can summarize these thoughts as: I've defined a machine that operates on stacks of dimensions and pops and pushes them according to the target spec ('the instructions'). This machine is useful because it lets us write simple 'programs' that decide the output shape and they work against many input shapes in a uniform way. This is good because we don't need to have say 3 or 4 new kinds of layers that hard-code these behaviors when a flexible spec can give us the same thing. 

But your question is really asking why this machine doesn't allow 'recursion' (embedding a code inside another code). And I think the answer is: I don't know what recursion should really do in this machine, and I don't think it would make the machine any more powerful. 

What do you think?

@piiswrong: any 'shape' that currently is valid will continue to be valid and have the same output. 

Some shapes that used to be invalid are now valid. For example, the shape `(3,0)` used to be invalid -- there was a check to prevent you manually setting a dimension (3) AND using the 0 code at the same time. 

There was nothing wrong such such a thing in principle, but I guess it was prevented because there wasn't a model for exactly what it should mean. The "stack machine" model that I've described is such a model, and furthermore it actually _wants_ you to be able to combine codes like `0` with fixed dimensions like `3`, so therefore I've removed that check.

TLDR: the design is 100% backward compatible.
LGTM

@sxjscience Yeah this will cut out a lot of code in our framework that were just there to redundantly track tensor dims for the purposes of feeding them to Reshape layer. I'm very excited about this. A small increase in (optional) complexity in Reshape layer pays off with a large decrease in complexity in our framework code.

@moveforever I agree these two ideas contract: 1) sparse inputs have variable length, because the actual vector length is the number of non-zero entries in that sparse record; 2) pre-allocating fixed memory buffers.  Also 3) minibatches, which acts a lot like (2).

I think a good way to solve this is by adopting a convention that a value of "-1" in the index input indicates that this entry should actually be treated as blank (sparse).  This means that sparse input data will have to be padded out to a fixed size of maximum number of non-zero entries.

Well, I want to make it clear that in order to comply the mxnet example style, I made several changes here in the example/ssd, thus the model is now slightly incompatible with the original repo. You will need to modify .params and .json in order to transfer model between these two repos now.  However I don't recommend to do this.

The divergence could be solved when I finally make a change to the original repo. I'm still reluctant to do so because breaking the compatibility in the same repo is not a good idea.

I'd feel a lot more confident if "Verify all the code in example folder run" was part of travis/jenkins CI.  I'm pretty sure they don't all run on 0.7.0, which is okay.  But we should make sure NNVM isn't breaking any of the ones that are working today.

HI Eric:

   Root cause found
   MXNet’s test case require to support moving mean &var as the same as GPU for both fix_gamma & not fix gamma case
   MKL team will provide the feature these weeks, and I will enable it as soon as possible.
   Below is the function to check consistency
def check_consistency(sym, ctx_list, scale=1.0, grad_req='write'):
   tol = {np.dtype(np.float16): 1e-1,
           np.dtype(np.float32): 1e-3,
           np.dtype(np.float64): 1e-5,
           np.dtype(np.uint8): 0,
           np.dtype(np.int32): 0}
    assert len(ctx_list) > 1
    exe_list = [sym.simple_bind(grad_req=grad_req, **ctx) for ctx in ctx_list]
    for exe in exe_list:
        assert len(exe.outputs) == 1
        assert len(exe.arg_arrays) == len(exe_list[0].arg_arrays)
        assert len(exe.grad_arrays) == len(exe_list[0].grad_arrays)

```
init = [np.random.normal(size=arr.shape, scale=scale) for arr in exe_list[0].arg_arrays]
if sym.name == 'embedding':
    init[0] = np.random.randint(low=0, high=10, size=exe_list[0].arg_arrays[0].shape)

for exe in exe_list:
    for arr, iarr in zip(exe.arg_arrays, init):
        arr[:] = iarr.astype(arr.dtype)

outputs_0 = [exe.outputs[0].asnumpy() for exe in exe_list]
grads_0 = [[grad.asnumpy() if grad is not None else np.zeros(1) for grad in exe.grad_arrays] for exe in exe_list]
# forward  //Not problem , since moving mean is 0 at the begining
for exe in exe_list:
    exe.forward(is_train=True)
    exe.backward(exe.outputs[0])

outputs = [exe.outputs[0].asnumpy() for exe in exe_list]
# lazy solution handling None grad
grads = [[grad.asnumpy() if grad is not None else np.zeros(1) for grad in exe.grad_arrays] for exe in exe_list]
dtypes = [arr.dtype for arr in outputs]
max_idx = np.argmax(dtypes)


//arg stand for BatchNormOpInputs {kData, kGamma, kBeta};
arg_arrays_1_0 = [exe.arg_arrays[0].asnumpy() for exe in exe_list]
arg_arrays_1_1 = [exe.arg_arrays[1].asnumpy() for exe in exe_list]
```

a, I think you should read the engine document. As to nnvm, I am not sure.

@GMarzinotto https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet-notebooks/blob/master/python/how_to/finetune.ipynb is a good example, but if you do not want to write code. Please use this branch:

https://github.com/taoari/mxnet/tree/finetune-api-20160726-round2

You may also need to first merge https://github.com/taoari/mxnet/tree/src-dev-20160726-round2 if you are using Inception-BN model, there are certain fixes for BatchNorm. But if you are happy with VGG, the merge is not necessary.

I am not rebasing on a newer version of MXNet, because I find that it is actually much slower than the old version (not sure if this is fixed on current latest).

I assume you converted the .rec files correctly, then here is a tested `solver.yml`:

```
network: vgg16
model_prefix: caltech101_finetune_vgg16
finetune_from: ../share/vgg/vgg16-0001.params

dataset: caltech101
data_dir: ../data/caltech101
train_dataset: train_ori.rec
val_dataset: val_ori.rec

data_shape: 3,224,224
num_classes: 102
num_examples: 3060
batch_size: 25

mean_values: 123,117,104
min_size: 256

lr: 0.0005
lr_factor: 0.1
lr_factor_epoch: 160
momentum: 0.9
wd: 0.0005

display: 50
eval_epoch: 8
checkpoint_epoch: 80
num_epochs: 400 # 2.5x lr_factor_epoch

kv_store: local
initializer: msra
```

Then use the following command to train:

```
python train_rec.py --solver solver.yml --gpus 0
```

And here is the symbol_vgg16.py converted from Caffe:

```
import find_mxnet
import mxnet as mx

def get_symbol(num_classes=1000, dataset='imagenet'):
    data = mx.symbol.Variable(name="data")
    with mx.AttrScope(weigt_lr_mult='1', bias_lr_mult='2'):
        conv1_1 = mx.symbol.Convolution(name='conv1_1', data=data , num_filter=64, pad=(1,1), kernel=(3,3), stride=(1,1), no_bias=False)
        relu1_1 = mx.symbol.Activation(name='relu1_1', data=conv1_1 , act_type='relu')
        conv1_2 = mx.symbol.Convolution(name='conv1_2', data=relu1_1 , num_filter=64, pad=(1,1), kernel=(3,3), stride=(1,1), no_bias=False)
        relu1_2 = mx.symbol.Activation(name='relu1_2', data=conv1_2 , act_type='relu')
        pool1 = mx.symbol.Pooling(name='pool1', data=relu1_2 , pad=(0,0), kernel=(2,2), stride=(2,2), pool_type='max')
        conv2_1 = mx.symbol.Convolution(name='conv2_1', data=pool1 , num_filter=128, pad=(1,1), kernel=(3,3), stride=(1,1), no_bias=False)
        relu2_1 = mx.symbol.Activation(name='relu2_1', data=conv2_1 , act_type='relu')
        conv2_2 = mx.symbol.Convolution(name='conv2_2', data=relu2_1 , num_filter=128, pad=(1,1), kernel=(3,3), stride=(1,1), no_bias=False)
        relu2_2 = mx.symbol.Activation(name='relu2_2', data=conv2_2 , act_type='relu')
        pool2 = mx.symbol.Pooling(name='pool2', data=relu2_2 , pad=(0,0), kernel=(2,2), stride=(2,2), pool_type='max')
        conv3_1 = mx.symbol.Convolution(name='conv3_1', data=pool2 , num_filter=256, pad=(1,1), kernel=(3,3), stride=(1,1), no_bias=False)
        relu3_1 = mx.symbol.Activation(name='relu3_1', data=conv3_1 , act_type='relu')
        conv3_2 = mx.symbol.Convolution(name='conv3_2', data=relu3_1 , num_filter=256, pad=(1,1), kernel=(3,3), stride=(1,1), no_bias=False)
        relu3_2 = mx.symbol.Activation(name='relu3_2', data=conv3_2 , act_type='relu')
        conv3_3 = mx.symbol.Convolution(name='conv3_3', data=relu3_2 , num_filter=256, pad=(1,1), kernel=(3,3), stride=(1,1), no_bias=False)
        relu3_3 = mx.symbol.Activation(name='relu3_3', data=conv3_3 , act_type='relu')
        pool3 = mx.symbol.Pooling(name='pool3', data=relu3_3 , pad=(0,0), kernel=(2,2), stride=(2,2), pool_type='max')
        conv4_1 = mx.symbol.Convolution(name='conv4_1', data=pool3 , num_filter=512, pad=(1,1), kernel=(3,3), stride=(1,1), no_bias=False)
        relu4_1 = mx.symbol.Activation(name='relu4_1', data=conv4_1 , act_type='relu')
        conv4_2 = mx.symbol.Convolution(name='conv4_2', data=relu4_1 , num_filter=512, pad=(1,1), kernel=(3,3), stride=(1,1), no_bias=False)
        relu4_2 = mx.symbol.Activation(name='relu4_2', data=conv4_2 , act_type='relu')
        conv4_3 = mx.symbol.Convolution(name='conv4_3', data=relu4_2 , num_filter=512, pad=(1,1), kernel=(3,3), stride=(1,1), no_bias=False)
        relu4_3 = mx.symbol.Activation(name='relu4_3', data=conv4_3 , act_type='relu')
        pool4 = mx.symbol.Pooling(name='pool4', data=relu4_3 , pad=(0,0), kernel=(2,2), stride=(2,2), pool_type='max')
        conv5_1 = mx.symbol.Convolution(name='conv5_1', data=pool4 , num_filter=512, pad=(1,1), kernel=(3,3), stride=(1,1), no_bias=False)
        relu5_1 = mx.symbol.Activation(name='relu5_1', data=conv5_1 , act_type='relu')
        conv5_2 = mx.symbol.Convolution(name='conv5_2', data=relu5_1 , num_filter=512, pad=(1,1), kernel=(3,3), stride=(1,1), no_bias=False)
        relu5_2 = mx.symbol.Activation(name='relu5_2', data=conv5_2 , act_type='relu')
        conv5_3 = mx.symbol.Convolution(name='conv5_3', data=relu5_2 , num_filter=512, pad=(1,1), kernel=(3,3), stride=(1,1), no_bias=False)
        relu5_3 = mx.symbol.Activation(name='relu5_3', data=conv5_3 , act_type='relu')
        pool5 = mx.symbol.Pooling(name='pool5', data=relu5_3 , pad=(0,0), kernel=(2,2), stride=(2,2), pool_type='max')
        flatten_0=mx.symbol.Flatten(name='flatten_0', data=pool5)
        fc6 = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(name='fc6', data=flatten_0 , num_hidden=4096, no_bias=False)
        relu6 = mx.symbol.Activation(name='relu6', data=fc6 , act_type='relu')
        drop6 = mx.symbol.Dropout(name='drop6', data=relu6 , p=0.500000)
        fc7 = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(name='fc7', data=drop6 , num_hidden=4096, no_bias=False)
        relu7 = mx.symbol.Activation(name='relu7', data=fc7 , act_type='relu')
        drop7 = mx.symbol.Dropout(name='drop7', data=relu7 , p=0.500000)
        if dataset == 'imagenet':
            fc8 = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(name='fc8', data=drop7 , num_hidden=num_classes, no_bias=False)
        else:
            fc8 = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(name='fc8_%s' % dataset, data=drop7 , num_hidden=num_classes, no_bias=False, 
                attr={'weight_lr_mult': '10', 'bias_lr_mult': '20'})
        prob = mx.symbol.SoftmaxOutput(name='softmax', data=fc8 )
    return prob
```

> preds <- predict(model, testdata)[1,]

Where should I add 'forward(is_train=TRUE)'? 

Many thanks.
I'm not familiar with the R API and I suggest you look into the implementation of `predict`, which will call the `mx.exec.forward`. You can do that by chaning the `is.train` flag to true.
Fine. I'll pull it soon.

Your advice was exactly right, thank you very much. For anyone else using R, the procedure was as follows:

#See code behind predict:
getAnywhere(predict.MXFeedForwardModel)

#Create modified predict function:
predict.MXFeedForwardModel**Dropout** <- function (identical to predict.MXFeedForwardModel but with 'mx.exec.forward(pexec, is.train = **TRUE**)'

#Add the modified function to the mxnet namespace:
environment(predict.MXFeedForwardModel**Dropout**) <- asNamespace("mxnet")

#Then specify modified function when predicting:
preds <- predict.MXFeedForwardModel**Dropout**(model, testdata)[1,]

Predictions are now different realisations each time.
The check fails because ROIPooling only supports positive batch ids. Try to change the 0s in https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/tests/python/unittest/test_operator.py#L1471 to 0.1.

@mli Also I think we should put some of the logic into functions and move them into the main repo.
Currently I frequently have to copy large chunk of code like argparser, log config, kv store create, model load/save

Here is an idea:

```

def log_config(log_dir=None, log_file=None, prefix=None, rank=0):
    reload(logging)
    head = '%(asctime)-15s Node[' + str(rank) + '] %(message)s'
    if log_dir:
        logging.basicConfig(level=logging.DEBUG, format=head)
        if not os.path.exists(log_dir):
            os.makedirs(log_dir)
        if not log_file:
            log_file = (prefix if prefix else '') + datetime.now().strftime('_%Y_%m_%d-%H_%M.log')
            log_file = log_file.replace('/', '-')
        else:
            log_file = log_file
        log_file_full_name = os.path.join(log_dir, log_file)
        handler = logging.FileHandler(log_file_full_name, mode='w')
        formatter = logging.Formatter(head)
        handler.setFormatter(formatter)
        logging.getLogger().addHandler(handler)
        logging.info('start with arguments %s', args)
    else:
        logging.basicConfig(level=logging.DEBUG, format=head)
        logging.info('start with arguments %s', args)
```

`bokeh=None` is cleaner.  I like that better than having to assert that it loaded every time.  It's not super friendly to end-users though.  They'll get an error message like `AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'figure'`.

Instead you could use:

```
try:
    import bokeh
except ImportError:
    class Bokeh_Failed_To_Import: pass
    bokeh = Bokeh_Failed_To_Import
```

then customers will see a message like `AttributeError: class Bokeh_Failed_To_Import has no attribute 'figure'` which is much easier to figure out how to fix.
I think Eric is saying that the class `LogValidationMetricsCallback` should be in the file https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/callback.py
